importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the occurrence of recent cross-border violence between Afghanistan and Pakistan, highlighting the ongoing instability in the region and the immediate diplomatic response to the breach of ceasefire.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 48-hour ceasefire initiated on 10/16 at 13:00 GMT was intended to bring temporary calm to the border region, but was violated by air attacks on 10/18, illustrating the fragility of peace agreements and the urgent need for diplomatic resolution.

keyTakeAways: Pakistan launched air attacks inside Afghanistan, killing at least 10 civilians, including two children, in Paktika province, breaking a previously agreed 48-hour ceasefire.
Afghan officials accuse Pakistan of targeting the Hafiz Gul Bahadur Group, a faction linked to the Pakistan Taliban (TTP), in retaliation for alleged attacks on Pakistani forces.

The Afghanistan Cricket Board (ACB) claims three cricketers and five others were killed during a gathering in Urgun district, calling the attack 'cowardly' and citing the Pakistani regime as responsible.
Afghanistan has withdrawn from the upcoming Tri-Nation T20I Series with Pakistan, expressing deep outrage over the attack on athletes.

Both countries are set to hold crisis talks in Doha, with Afghan Defense Minister Mullah Muhammad Yaqoob and Pakistani Defence Minister Khawaja Asif and Intelligence Chief General Asim Malik attending.
The violence has intensified since a prior explosion in Kabul, which coincided with the Taliban’s foreign minister visiting India, Pakistan’s long-standing rival, heightening regional tensions.
The UN Assistance Mission in Afghanistan reported 37 fatalities and 425 injuries on the Afghan side of the border, urging both sides to pursue a lasting ceasefire.
Public sentiment in affected areas shows a mix of fear and hope; while some residents are considering fleeing, others maintain normal daily routines, reflecting the uncertainty of the situation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Afghanistan accuses Pakistan of violating a 48-hour ceasefire by launching air strikes in Paktika province, killing at least 10 civilians, including two children. The attacks, targeting a local faction linked to the Pakistan Taliban (TTP), have been condemned by Afghan officials, who claim the strikes were retaliatory for a previous attack in Pakistan's FATA region. The Afghanistan Cricket Board reports that three cricketers and five others were killed during a peaceful gathering, leading it to withdraw from an upcoming series with Pakistan. Both countries are preparing for crisis talks in Doha to address the escalation. The violence follows a week of intense border clashes, with 37 Afghan casualties reported by the UN and widespread fear among civilians, though some report temporary normalcy. The incident reflects deep-rooted security tensions, with both nations accusing each other of harboring extremist groups, and underscores the vulnerability of civilians and cultural institutions in conflict zones.
title: Afghanistan accuses Pakistan of breaking truce as 10 killed in air attacks
